title: What is phantom traffic and why is it ruining your life? - Benjamin Seibold

multiple-choice.question: What is a "phantom traffic jam"?

options.label: A
options.text: A traffic jam caused by an accident or road closure

options.label: B
options.text: A traffic jam caused by a sudden change in speed limit

options.label: C
options.text: A traffic jam that occurs for no apparent reason

options.label: D
options.text: A traffic jam caused by a narrowing of the road

multiple-choice.question: What is the critical density of cars on the road that can lead to a phantom traffic jam?

options.label: A
options.text: When cars are spaced more than 50 meters apart

options.label: B
options.text: When cars are spaced less than 35 meters apart

options.label: C
options.text: When cars are spaced exactly 20 meters apart

options.label: D
options.text: When cars are spaced more than 100 meters apart

multiple-choice.question: What is dynamic instability, and how does it relate to phantom traffic jams?

options.label: A
options.text: Dynamic instability is a negative feedback loop that reduces traffic congestion

options.label: B
options.text: Dynamic instability is a positive feedback loop that amplifies small disturbances in traffic

options.label: C
options.text: Dynamic instability is a type of traffic signal that helps to regulate traffic flow

options.label: D
options.text: Dynamic instability is a type of road surface that can cause traffic jams

multiple-choice.question: How can self-driving cars help to prevent phantom traffic jams?

options.label: A
options.text: By accelerating rapidly out of a slowdown

options.label: B
options.text: By braking harder to avoid a collision

options.label: C
options.text: By maintaining a uniform speed that matches the average speed of the overall flow

multiple-choice.question: According to a recent experiment, what percentage of self-driving cars is needed to dampen and prevent traffic waves?

options.label: D
options.text: One autonomous vehicle for every 20 human drivers

title: NASA’s first software engineer: Margaret Hamilton - Matt Porter and Margaret Hamilton

multiple-choice.question: What was Margaret Hamilton's role in the Apollo 11 mission?

options.label: A
options.text: She was the lead astronaut on the mission.

options.label: B
options.text: She was the lead engineer for the Apollo Guidance Computer hardware.

options.label: C
options.text: She led the team developing the pioneering in-flight software.

options.label: D
options.text: She was the Mission Control leader.

multiple-choice.question: What was the major challenge faced by Margaret Hamilton's team while developing the Apollo Guidance Computer software?

options.label: A
options.text: The software had to be able to process jobs in a predetermined order.

options.label: B
options.text: The software had to be able to detect unexpected errors and recover from them in real time.

options.label: C
options.text: The software had to be able to operate without any human input.

options.label: D
options.text: The software had to be able to fit in a large room.

multiple-choice.question: How did Margaret Hamilton's software handle unexpected errors?

options.label: A
options.text: It would shut down the system and require manual restart.

options.label: B
options.text: It would prioritize tasks and interrupt less important ones to handle the error.

options.label: C
options.text: It would ignore the error and continue with the scheduled tasks.

options.label: D
options.text: It would alert Mission Control but not take any action.

multiple-choice.question: What was the cause of the emergency alarm that lit up just before the lunar landing?

options.label: A
options.text: A software bug in the Apollo Guidance Computer.

options.label: B
options.text: A hardware failure in the Apollo Guidance Computer.

options.label: C
options.text: Buzz Aldrin inadvertently flipping the rendezvous radar switch.

options.label: D
options.text: A communication error between the astronauts and Mission Control.

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of Margaret Hamilton's work on the Apollo 11 mission?

options.label: A
options.text: The mission was aborted due to software errors.

options.label: B
options.text: The mission was successful, but the software had several bugs.

options.label: C
options.text: The mission was successful, and no bugs were ever found in the in-flight software.

options.label: D
options.text: The mission was delayed due to software issues.

title: Inside the mind of a master procrastinator - Tim Urban

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the primary reason why procrastinators struggle to complete tasks on time?

options.label: A
options.text: They lack motivation and interest in the task.

options.label: B
options.text: They are easily distracted by social media and other digital platforms.

options.label: C
options.text: They have an Instant Gratification Monkey in their brain that prioritizes short-term pleasure over long-term goals.

options.label: D
options.text: They are not intelligent or capable enough to complete the task.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the Panic Monster in the procrastinator's system?

options.label: A
options.text: To motivate the procrastinator to start working on a task.

options.label: B
options.text: To distract the procrastinator from the task at hand.

options.label: C
options.text: To take control of the procrastinator's brain and make rational decisions.

options.label: D
options.text: To wake up when a deadline is near and prompt the procrastinator to take action.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the difference between short-term and long-term procrastination?

options.label: A
options.text: Short-term procrastination is more severe and has greater consequences.

options.label: B
options.text: Long-term procrastination is more visible and widely discussed.

options.label: C
options.text: Short-term procrastination is contained to a specific deadline, while long-term procrastination has no deadline and can extend outward forever.

options.label: D
options.text: Short-term procrastination is a sign of laziness, while long-term procrastination is a sign of intelligence.

multiple-choice.question: What is the Life Calendar that the speaker refers to?

options.label: A
options.text: A tool for tracking deadlines and appointments.

options.label: B
options.text: A visual representation of a 90-year life, divided into boxes for each week.

options.label: C
options.text: A method for prioritizing tasks and managing time.

options.label: D
options.text: A system for rewarding oneself for completing tasks.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the ultimate goal of recognizing and understanding the Instant Gratification Monkey and the procrastinator's system?

options.label: A
options.text: To eliminate procrastination entirely and become a perfect time manager.

options.label: B
options.text: To develop strategies for managing the Monkey and staying focused on long-term goals.

options.label: C
options.text: To accept procrastination as a natural part of life and give up trying to change.

options.label: D
options.text: To blame the Monkey for one's lack of productivity and avoid taking responsibility.

options.text: Grit is directly related to talent.

options.label: B
options.text: Grit is inversely related to talent.

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
